KH.content: leave khōra untranslated, thinking & translation here traverse the same experience/experiment (expérience): “place,” “location,” “region,” “country” & its figures, “mother,” “nurse,” “receptacle,” “imprint-bearer” [see p. 126, these figures not even true figures]
KH.linkedContent: leave khōra untranslated, thinking & translation here traverse the same experience/experiment (expérience): “place,” “location,” “region,” “country” & its figures, “mother,” “nurse,” “receptacle,” “imprint-bearer” [see p. 126, these figures not even true figures]

GT.content: can one ask these questions (i.e. what is a gift?) w/out anticipating a thought?
GT.linkedContent: can one ask these questions (i.e. what is a gift?) w/out anticipating a thought?

R.content: Aristotle’s Prime Mover, the first desirable, gives a life that exceeds the life of a human, continuous, unending—for us, impossible
R.linkedContent: Aristotle’s Prime Mover, the first desirable, gives a life that exceeds the life of a human, continuous, unending—for us, impossible

R.content: energeia of this pure activity is “pleasure (hēdonē), circle of taking pleasure in oneself (jouissance de soi); a specular auto-affection that accords w/ thinking of thought
R.linkedContent: energeia of this pure activity is “pleasure (hēdonē), circle of taking pleasure in oneself (jouissance de soi); a specular auto-affection that accords w/ thinking of thought

MONL.content: for Heidegger, Zusage primary to question, the most irreducible in thought
MONL.linkedContent: for Heidegger, Zusage primary to question, the most irreducible in thought

H.content: p. anne 28 “thought is in essence a force of mastery…breaking up the unknown to possess it, shed light on it, name it”
H.linkedContent: p. anne 28 “thought is in essence a force of mastery…breaking up the unknown to possess it, shed light on it, name it”

H.content: pp. anne 54-6 step beyond border, threshold, because inability to mark a stable territory provokes thought
H.linkedContent: pp. anne 54-6 step beyond border, threshold, because inability to mark a stable territory provokes thought

H.content: p. anne 152 a place of haunting has no ghosts, ghosts come where they are excluded, death haunts us by remaining unthought
H.linkedContent: p. anne 152 a place of haunting has no ghosts, ghosts come where they are excluded, death haunts us by remaining unthought

OOG.content: phenomenology never had to learn that Thought would always be to come
OOG.linkedContent: phenomenology never had to learn that Thought would always be to come

SPOM.content: no pure identity if that which is most living have specters inside, weighed down by specters, which think
SPOM.linkedContent: no pure identity if that which is most living have specters inside, weighed down by specters, which think

SPOM.content: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]
SPOM.linkedContent: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]

SPOM.content: via Marx, practical events, where thought becomes act (se fait agir); thought as Handeln in Heidegger
SPOM.linkedContent: via Marx, practical events, where thought becomes act (se fait agir); thought as Handeln in Heidegger

POOF.content: via Aristotle’s prótē philía as teleía philía, telos of friendship as that which can’t be reached, inconceivable, self-contradictory, would be the desire for a perfect friend, for a friendship w/ God [Derrida offers 3 reasons why this is impossible]
POOF.linkedContent: via Aristotle’s prótē philía as teleía philía, telos of friendship as that which can’t be reached, inconceivable, self-contradictory, would be the desire for a perfect friend, for a friendship w/ God [Derrida offers 3 reasons why this is impossible]

POOF.content: if man has friends, it’s because he thinks the other, thought of the other as thought of the mortal, and thus there is only thought in friendship > “O my friends…” the declaration of God, who knows only divine friendship
POOF.linkedContent: if man has friends, it’s because he thinks the other, thought of the other as thought of the mortal, and thus there is only thought in friendship > “O my friends…” the declaration of God, who knows only divine friendship

POR.content: reason only one species of thought
POR.linkedContent: reason only one species of thought

POR.content: “thinking” requires both principle of reason and what’s beyond it, both archē and an-archy > decision [of thought] always risks the worst, to claim to erase the risk by institutional program is to create a barricade against a future
POR.linkedContent: “thinking” requires both principle of reason and what’s beyond it, both archē and an-archy > decision [of thought] always risks the worst, to claim to erase the risk by institutional program is to create a barricade against a future

MPM.content: thinking, not bereaved interiorization, thinks at boundaries, thinks the boundary, the limit of interiority
MPM.linkedContent: thinking, not bereaved interiorization, thinks at boundaries, thinks the boundary, the limit of interiority

MPM.content: Heidegger: is memory a container for thought [Gedachtes]? or does thinking rest in memory [Gedächtnis]?
MPM.linkedContent: Heidegger: is memory a container for thought [Gedachtes]? or does thinking rest in memory [Gedächtnis]?

MPM.content: Heidegger rethinks “thought (Gedanke)” w/ Gedanc, bottom of the heart, gathering together of all that concerns us, more original than Pascal’s thinking of heart? [Dank]
MPM.linkedContent: Heidegger rethinks “thought (Gedanke)” w/ Gedanc, bottom of the heart, gathering together of all that concerns us, more original than Pascal’s thinking of heart? [Dank]

VM.content: for face to present other w/out metaphor, speech must not only translate thought, thought must already be speech
VM.linkedContent: for face to present other w/out metaphor, speech must not only translate thought, thought must already be speech

VM.content: dissociation of thought and language, subordination of latter to former, is proper to philosophy of finitude [Cartesian Cogito of 3rd Meditation]
VM.linkedContent: dissociation of thought and language, subordination of latter to former, is proper to philosophy of finitude [Cartesian Cogito of 3rd Meditation]

VM.content: classical infinitism of Cartesian type, thought goes much further much faster than language [thought vs. body (language)?], would handle questions re: Levinas’ other by neutralizing space to liberate positive infinity
VM.linkedContent: classical infinitism of Cartesian type, thought goes much further much faster than language [thought vs. body (language)?], would handle questions re: Levinas’ other by neutralizing space to liberate positive infinity

VM.content: Greek logos not accidental for any thought; Greek miracle is impossibility for any thought to treat its sages as “sages of the outside” > by proferring epekeina tes ousias, by welcoming alterity into heart of logos, it has protected itself against every surprising convocation
VM.linkedContent: Greek logos not accidental for any thought; Greek miracle is impossibility for any thought to treat its sages as “sages of the outside” > by proferring epekeina tes ousias, by welcoming alterity into heart of logos, it has protected itself against every surprising convocation

VP.content: Husserl tormented by possibility that writing inhabits inside of speech, itself at work in intimacy of thought
VP.linkedContent: Husserl tormented by possibility that writing inhabits inside of speech, itself at work in intimacy of thought

PAS.content: event (de-distance of near) (Eriegnis, Entfernung, Enteignis) “before” which philosophy and its pas au déla (thought) are trying to close themselves
PAS.linkedContent: event (de-distance of near) (Eriegnis, Entfernung, Enteignis) “before” which philosophy and its pas au déla (thought) are trying to close themselves

S.content: Heidegger: the more original the thought, the richer its unthought, the unthought is the highest gift a thought can give
S.linkedContent: Heidegger: the more original the thought, the richer its unthought, the unthought is the highest gift a thought can give

S.content: to name spirit is to offer for thinking, German only language in which spirit comes to name itself
S.linkedContent: to name spirit is to offer for thinking, German only language in which spirit comes to name itself

S.content: promise as the promise of the day before the day before; acc. Heidegger, there’s a “must” a “we must think” of the promise, thought as fidelity to promise > must hear & obey
S.linkedContent: promise as the promise of the day before the day before; acc. Heidegger, there’s a “must” a “we must think” of the promise, thought as fidelity to promise > must hear & obey

PPHS.content: Hegel: German language bestowed direct kinship btwn Gedächtnis and Gedanke
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: German language bestowed direct kinship btwn Gedächtnis and Gedanke

PPHS.content: Hegel: “we think in names” [magic?] ex: “lion” [Hegel contradicts privilege of sign?]
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: “we think in names” [magic?] ex: “lion” [Hegel contradicts privilege of sign?]

PPHS.content: Hegel: number is pure thought of thought’s externalization, in number sense is brought closest to thought > thoughtlessness, indifference, number remains sensuous
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: number is pure thought of thought’s externalization, in number sense is brought closest to thought > thoughtlessness, indifference, number remains sensuous

SH.content: the resistance thought of “once” gives one to think, let’s let ourselves be approached by this offering
SH.linkedContent: the resistance thought of “once” gives one to think, let’s let ourselves be approached by this offering

SH.content: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]
SH.linkedContent: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]

FWT.content: safe and sound—beautiful freedom of human thought [juxtaposed to physiologistic determinism] [Scientology, Going Clear] [moral image of thought]
FWT.linkedContent: safe and sound—beautiful freedom of human thought [juxtaposed to physiologistic determinism] [Scientology, Going Clear] [moral image of thought]

POS.content: Derrida’s suspicion of “thought,” that it means nothing, that it is logocentric > substantified void of highly derivative ideality [Deleuze’s moral image of thought]
POS.linkedContent: Derrida’s suspicion of “thought,” that it means nothing, that it is logocentric > substantified void of highly derivative ideality [Deleuze’s moral image of thought]

OS.content: Heidegger designates milieu of self-evidence, outside which thought suffocates > has not entire philosophy been authorized on “extraordinary right” of present? for Heidegger, it’s not a question of thinking otherwise, it’s thinking that which could not have been, nor thought, otherwise ——the impossibility of the otherwise produces a trembling, a question of tout autre, think the tie btwn truth/presence, in a thought that doesn’t need to be true/present [no skeptical moment]
OS.linkedContent: Heidegger designates milieu of self-evidence, outside which thought suffocates > has not entire philosophy been authorized on “extraordinary right” of present? for Heidegger, it’s not a question of thinking otherwise, it’s thinking that which could not have been, nor thought, otherwise ——the impossibility of the otherwise produces a trembling, a question of tout autre, think the tie btwn truth/presence, in a thought that doesn’t need to be true/present [no skeptical moment]

OS.content: transition from parousia to absolute subjectivity does not disrupt Aristotelianism: prime mover, presence, desire, eros, “desire is desire of presence,” absolute subjectivity, circle, return to self, parousia as self-presence > prime mover, noēsis noēseōs, as subject
OS.linkedContent: transition from parousia to absolute subjectivity does not disrupt Aristotelianism: prime mover, presence, desire, eros, “desire is desire of presence,” absolute subjectivity, circle, return to self, parousia as self-presence > prime mover, noēsis noēseōs, as subject

ROP.content: thought conditioned (exercent) by fidelity, fidelity honed (aiguisent) by thought
ROP.linkedContent: thought conditioned (exercent) by fidelity, fidelity honed (aiguisent) by thought

ATIA.content: to think the war we find ourselves waging [against animals] is not only a duty, no one can escape it: thinking, perhaps, begins when animal looks at us and we are naked before it
ATIA.linkedContent: to think the war we find ourselves waging [against animals] is not only a duty, no one can escape it: thinking, perhaps, begins when animal looks at us and we are naked before it

ATIA.content: properly phenomenological logic of “I am” means there is only “I think” > breath, life are secondary: “I breathe, therefore I am” concludes nothing > indubitability of existence depends on thought (not being-in-life)
ATIA.linkedContent: properly phenomenological logic of “I am” means there is only “I think” > breath, life are secondary: “I breathe, therefore I am” concludes nothing > indubitability of existence depends on thought (not being-in-life)

FS.content: for Leibniz, man is finite in act, infinite in thought; in God act/thought coexist
FS.linkedContent: for Leibniz, man is finite in act, infinite in thought; in God act/thought coexist

WAP.content: “thinking,” which entitles only this “no” of no pure instance, must, in the name of a democracy to come, “unremittingly interrogate” (that is deconstruct) the de facto democracy, its determinations > event/promise whose singularity doesn’t signify (self-) presence
WAP.linkedContent: “thinking,” which entitles only this “no” of no pure instance, must, in the name of a democracy to come, “unremittingly interrogate” (that is deconstruct) the de facto democracy, its determinations > event/promise whose singularity doesn’t signify (self-) presence

CHM.content: madness rejected form very interiority of thought itself [Foucault on Descartes]
CHM.linkedContent: madness rejected form very interiority of thought itself [Foucault on Descartes]

CHM.content: Montaigne haunted by thought of going mad in very action of thought itself
CHM.linkedContent: Montaigne haunted by thought of going mad in very action of thought itself

CHM.content: for Descartes, thinking and saying what is clear & distinct is same thing—Derrida adds that, for St. Anselm, the insipiens, the insane man, couldn’t think because he couldn’t think what he said > madness as voluble silence that couldn’t think its own words
CHM.linkedContent: for Descartes, thinking and saying what is clear & distinct is same thing—Derrida adds that, for St. Anselm, the insipiens, the insane man, couldn’t think because he couldn’t think what he said > madness as voluble silence that couldn’t think its own words

Gii.content: Heidegger: thinking is genuine activity, lend a hand to the essence
Gii.linkedContent: Heidegger: thinking is genuine activity, lend a hand to the essence

Gii.content: thinking of the hand, hand of thinking > thinking of human Geschlecht (not a humanism? or not a metaphysical, classical humanism?)
Gii.linkedContent: thinking of the hand, hand of thinking > thinking of human Geschlecht (not a humanism? or not a metaphysical, classical humanism?)

Gii.content: acc. Heidegger, sciences belong to essence of technology, not to technology—to its essence; technology remains plunged in a fog (noyée dans un brouillard) > we still do not think (science, no one, is responsible for this) > the most thought-provoking (das Bedenklichste): we still do not think ——for Heidegger, thinking as work of cabinetmaker (Schreiner), a joiner, attune to hidden plenitude of wood’s essence as it enters inhabited site, Handwerk
Gii.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, sciences belong to essence of technology, not to technology—to its essence; technology remains plunged in a fog (noyée dans un brouillard) > we still do not think (science, no one, is responsible for this) > the most thought-provoking (das Bedenklichste): we still do not think ——for Heidegger, thinking as work of cabinetmaker (Schreiner), a joiner, attune to hidden plenitude of wood’s essence as it enters inhabited site, Handwerk

Gii.content: Heidegger: the hand is constantly in danger, writing of poetry too
Gii.linkedContent: Heidegger: the hand is constantly in danger, writing of poetry too

Gii.content: to think is a handiwork [w/out any perhaps] > elsewhere in Heidegger, thought is linked to Lichtung, to eye, or to hearing/voice—now to hand
Gii.linkedContent: to think is a handiwork [w/out any perhaps] > elsewhere in Heidegger, thought is linked to Lichtung, to eye, or to hearing/voice—now to hand

Gii.content: thinking is neither cerebral nor disincarnate
Gii.linkedContent: thinking is neither cerebral nor disincarnate

Gii.content: for Heidegger, hand thinks before being thought > it is thought, a thought, thinking
Gii.linkedContent: for Heidegger, hand thinks before being thought > it is thought, a thought, thinking

Gii.content: Heidegger: only when man speaks does he think, not the other way around, as metaphysics still believes
Gii.linkedContent: Heidegger: only when man speaks does he think, not the other way around, as metaphysics still believes

Gii.content: Heidegger: work of hand, thought, man’s hardest & simplest work
hand gives & gives itself: animal rationale can only take, grasp [anti-Hegel, whose concept is the graspable] [Derrida refers to GT, where giving & taking are problematized]
Gii.linkedContent: hand gives & gives itself: animal rationale can only take, grasp [anti-Hegel, whose concept is the graspable] [Derrida refers to GT, where giving & taking are problematized]

Gii.content: acc. Heidegger, Socrates is purest thinker of West, wrote nothing, placed himself in the draft—withdrawing movement, in Zug (pull) of withdrawal (des Entziehens)
Gii.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Socrates is purest thinker of West, wrote nothing, placed himself in the draft—withdrawing movement, in Zug (pull) of withdrawal (des Entziehens)

Gii.content: logo-phonocentrism in Heidegger: writing declines thought, escapes draft when it enters literature [Derrida briefly directs us to Heidegger’s meditation on chreōn, Brauch, necessity, logos]
Gii.linkedContent: logo-phonocentrism in Heidegger: writing declines thought, escapes draft when it enters literature [Derrida briefly directs us to Heidegger’s meditation on chreōn, Brauch, necessity, logos]

Gii.content: for Heidegger, philosophy & science never attain the parallelism, the cutting/breaching (into one another), of thinking/philosophy (Denken) & poetry (Dichten)
Gii.linkedContent: for Heidegger, philosophy & science never attain the parallelism, the cutting/breaching (into one another), of thinking/philosophy (Denken) & poetry (Dichten)

DST.content: thinking of translation, experience of thinking itself, its most essential & risky passage, where experience of thinking is also poetic experience: privileged examples (in Lacoue-Labarthe): Gestell, mimesis, rhuthmos
DST.linkedContent: thinking of translation, experience of thinking itself, its most essential & risky passage, where experience of thinking is also poetic experience: privileged examples (in Lacoue-Labarthe): Gestell, mimesis, rhuthmos

DST.content: [re: Lacoue-Labarthe’s désistance] exemplary, superior probity that, w/out ceding to dogmatic moralism, submits ethical demand to trial (l’épreuve) of thought
DST.linkedContent: [re: Lacoue-Labarthe’s désistance] exemplary, superior probity that, w/out ceding to dogmatic moralism, submits ethical demand to trial (l’épreuve) of thought

DST.content: Derrida has his doubts when Lacoue-Labarthe argues that Heidegger’s unthought (impensé) gathers in unity of single site, as if there were only one unthought for each “great” thought—as its secret law
DST.linkedContent: Derrida has his doubts when Lacoue-Labarthe argues that Heidegger’s unthought (impensé) gathers in unity of single site, as if there were only one unthought for each “great” thought—as its secret law

DST.content: Derrida wonders if Heidegger’s insistence on Ort, Erörterung, a unique site of gathering, leaves un-thought désistance or dislocation, which might be thought itself [this torments Derrida’s respect for Heidegger, along w/ Derrida’s insufficient concern re: authentic thought]
DST.linkedContent: Derrida wonders if Heidegger’s insistence on Ort, Erörterung, a unique site of gathering, leaves un-thought désistance or dislocation, which might be thought itself [this torments Derrida’s respect for Heidegger, along w/ Derrida’s insufficient concern re: authentic thought]

RM.content: neighborhood (voisinage, Nachbarschaft) of Dichten and Denken: vicus, veicus, which perhaps refers to oikos and Sanskrit veca
RM.linkedContent: neighborhood (voisinage, Nachbarschaft) of Dichten and Denken: vicus, veicus, which perhaps refers to oikos and Sanskrit veca

RM.content: entamées, les deux parallèles se coupent à l’infini, se recoupent, s’entaillent: each one [Denken and Dichten] signs in some way in the body of the other, the one in the place (au lieu) of the other: sign there the contract w/out contract of their neighborhood
RM.linkedContent: entamées, les deux parallèles se coupent à l’infini, se recoupent, s’entaillent: each one [Denken and Dichten] signs in some way in the body of the other, the one in the place (au lieu) of the other: sign there the contract w/out contract of their neighborhood

PF.content: only know what thought means by way of what resists/remains to be thought, thought remains to be thought
PF.linkedContent: only know what thought means by way of what resists/remains to be thought, thought remains to be thought

HLP.content: trying to think, by answering for its memory [re: history of the lie]
HLP.linkedContent: trying to think, by answering for its memory [re: history of the lie]

TR.content: event & calculable program (machine) together > no future w/out this thought
event-machine: change very name of what we call “thought” (now a homonym, paleonym)
TR.linkedContent: event-machine: change very name of what we call “thought” (now a homonym, paleonym)

IW.content: Rosenzweig sees Cohen as a philosopher-teacher who reminds us of the abyssal risk of thought or existence
IW.linkedContent: Rosenzweig sees Cohen as a philosopher-teacher who reminds us of the abyssal risk of thought or existence

PJP.content: “re-mind”: already a mnemotechnics at heart of & not outside the thinking of thought [cf. Nietzsche’s On the Genea…]
PJP.linkedContent: “re-mind”: already a mnemotechnics at heart of & not outside the thinking of thought [cf. Nietzsche’s On the Genea…]

D.content: no one can enter Soller’s Numbers who thinks literature/thought ought to exorcise the machine (that the 2 have nothing to do w/ each other)
D.linkedContent: no one can enter Soller’s Numbers who thinks literature/thought ought to exorcise the machine (that the 2 have nothing to do w/ each other)

LI.content: thought, relation to other, “experience” of differance

TN.content: the move from body extension to extension of psyche/thinking is incommensurable > a place (lieu) neither of objective space nor extension: place (lieu) as spacing before space
TN.linkedContent: the move from body extension to extension of psyche/thinking is incommensurable > a place (lieu) neither of objective space nor extension: place (lieu) as spacing before space

TN.content: Nancy: “the incommensurable extension of thinking is the opening of the mouth” > mouth as union of soul/body; Nancy accords decisive authority to “quasi” in Descartes’ “quasi permixtio”
TN.linkedContent: Nancy: “the incommensurable extension of thinking is the opening of the mouth” > mouth as union of soul/body; Nancy accords decisive authority to “quasi” in Descartes’ “quasi permixtio”

TN.content: Nancy moves from Psyche is extended to body weighs (i.e. thinks) [penser, peser]
TN.linkedContent: Nancy moves from Psyche is extended to body weighs (i.e. thinks) [penser, peser]

TN.content: Nancy: “la pensée pèse exactement le poids du sens” (Derrida points out transitive/intransitive double meaning of pèse)
TN.linkedContent: Nancy: “la pensée pèse exactement le poids du sens” (Derrida points out transitive/intransitive double meaning of pèse)

TN.content: Diderot, in tradition of Anaxagoras: “man thinks because he has hands”
TN.linkedContent: Diderot, in tradition of Anaxagoras: “man thinks because he has hands”

TN.content: insistence that comes down to thinking, no longer a simple rhetorical movement
TN.linkedContent: insistence that comes down to thinking, no longer a simple rhetorical movement

TN.content: malgré la pensée, thought thinks only in spite of itself, never begins by itself [Nancy’s peser]
TN.linkedContent: malgré la pensée, thought thinks only in spite of itself, never begins by itself [Nancy’s peser]

NOY.content: when thought and the word (la parole) given in writing merge (se confond) at the heart of the same time (au coeur du même temps)
NOY.linkedContent: when thought and the word (la parole) given in writing merge (se confond) at the heart of the same time (au coeur du même temps)

OG.content: [vis-à-vis Heidegger] thought of trace, perfectly neutral name, never has weight in system, blank part of text: what we already know we haven’t done
OG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Heidegger] thought of trace, perfectly neutral name, never has weight in system, blank part of text: what we already know we haven’t done

OG.content: thinking (what we already know we haven’t begun), “mesuré à la taille de l’écriture, s’entame seulement dans l’epistémè” > in a certain manner, thought gives you nothing to say
OG.linkedContent: thinking (what we already know we haven’t begun), “mesuré à la taille de l’écriture, s’entame seulement dans l’epistémè” > in a certain manner, thought gives you nothing to say

ATAP.content: for Heidegger, thought (not philosophy) essentially eschatological

EU.content: for Schelling, thinking as Einbildungskraft, as post-Kantian originary unity > all differences translations of same > post-critical, critique of critique
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, thinking as Einbildungskraft, as post-Kantian originary unity > all differences translations of same > post-critical, critique of critique

EU.content: most post-Kantians (incl. Nietzsche [?]) claim to have already reached the inaccessible: to think finitude, you have already thought the infinite (this becomes definition of thinking)
EU.linkedContent: most post-Kantians (incl. Nietzsche [?]) claim to have already reached the inaccessible: to think finitude, you have already thought the infinite (this becomes definition of thinking)

EU.content: post-Kantians accuse Kant of founding “criticism” in denegation, more responsible to found thought in inaccessible
EU.linkedContent: post-Kantians accuse Kant of founding “criticism” in denegation, more responsible to found thought in inaccessible

EU.content: [CIPH] no preinterpretation, “thinking” as what questions philosophy > indeterminate opening (experimental incursions in unexplored areas)
EU.linkedContent: [CIPH] no preinterpretation, “thinking” as what questions philosophy > indeterminate opening (experimental incursions in unexplored areas)

CHOR.content: [cf. WBH p. 198] could femininity, however irreducible it may be, remain derived from or subordinated to question of destination or thought of gift?
CHOR.linkedContent: [cf. WBH p. 198] could femininity, however irreducible it may be, remain derived from or subordinated to question of destination or thought of gift?

CHOR.content: Derrida uses word “thought,” which is also excessive, instead of philosophy, theory, logic, structure, scene
CHOR.linkedContent: Derrida uses word “thought,” which is also excessive, instead of philosophy, theory, logic, structure, scene
